Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Simultaneous 4D Flamelet and Velocity Diagnostics for Resolving Flamelet/Flow Interactions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1505112
PI: Ma, Lin

Turbulent combustion is a fundamental process of significant scientific and practical importance. Turbulent flames are inherently three-dimensional in space and dynamic in time. Until now, experimental techniques to measure turbulent flames have been limited to measurements at a point, along a line, or across a plane, and they do not fully resolve the three-dimensional structure of the flame. This project will conduct four-dimensional measurements that resolve the flame in all three spatial directions and time with precise resolution, which will improve our understanding of turbulent combustion. Turbulent combustion is the key process in many devices that dominate energy production. Improving our understanding of turbulent combustion will lead to the design of more efficient and cleaner energy devices. The project will also employ internet resources to develop learning platforms for a larger audience, to disseminate results to a wider community, and to increase public awareness of energy, environmental, and information technology issues.

This goal of this project is to obtain instantaneous and simultaneous 4D measurements of multiple properties key to the turbulent combustion processes. The project will apply 3D tomographic diagnostics recently developed by the PI to resolve flamelet/flow interactions in turbulent flames. The target properties include 3D flame surface density, flame volume, flame curvature, fractal dimension, 3D3C (three-dimensional, three-component) velocity fields, and also potentially local strain rate and turbulent flame speed. The success of this project will enable measurements of such properties in 4D for representative turbulent flames, and to establish multidimensional datasets that can be used for the development of computational tools for designing new energy devices. Furthermore, the project combines several distinct disciplines, including optical imaging, computed tomography, combustion, and the processing and analysis of large datasets. Results from the project will benefit practitioners in energy, photonics, and information technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flamelet and flow interactions represent a key fundamental scientific problem with practical relevance to a wide range of power devices, ranging from furnaces to gas turbine engines. However, our current understanding of such interactions remains far from complete, and the design of more efficient and cleaner power devices suffers from such incomplete understanding. Three-dimensional (3D) spatial structures and rapid temporal dynamics are inherent to the interactions. While numerical tools, notably LES (large eddy simulation) and DNS (direct numerical simulation), are becoming increasingly feasible to simulate the 3D and time-dependent structures of turbulent flames, the validation and further improvement of these tools have been severely limited by the lack of corresponding experimental data.

This project therefore aimed at enabling instantaneous 4D measurements that can resolve both the 3D spatial features and temporal dynamics of key flame/flow properties. Under this context, the project?s specific research goals are twofold. The first goal is to invent and develop new imaging techniques that can be applied in turbulent flames to obtain 4D measurements of key properties experimentally. And the second goal is to quantify and enhance the accuracy of 4D measurements in reactive flows, so that the data can be used for quantitative model comparison. Notable research outcomes toward the first goal included both new experimental and analytical techniques. Experimentally, we have developed and demonstrated instantaneous 4D techniques based on volumetric laser induced fluorescence (code named VLIF), where we extended the traditional 2D planar LIF (PLIF) technique to 3D measurements by combining LIF with tomographic imaging.  We also studied a hybrid technique combining VLIF with scanning to optimize the dimension of the measurement domain and the spatial resolution. Analytically, we have developed a new inversion technique to integrate tomographic reconstruction with view calibration. Our work has shown that measurement accuracy can be enhanced substantially by this new inversion technique compared to traditional practice of treating tomography and view calibration separately. Toward the second goal, we have designed and conducted controlled experimental measurements so that the uncertainty of tomographic particle imaging velocimetry (PIV) can be quantified and the impact due to beam steering can be isolated in reactive flows. These results are expected to provide insight and guidance to the quantitative interpretation of 3D velocity measurements in reactive flows and the use of such measurements for model comparison.

The intellectual merit of this work stems from both the fundamental scientific significance of flame-flow interaction and also its ubiquitous application in a wide range of practical devices. Existing experimental capabilities available to resolve such interactions are limited in various ways such as spatiotemporal resolution, dimensionality, and accuracy. The new tools developed in this project are expected to help overcome these limitations and to provide new capabilities long desired. These new capabilities have been demonstrated to enable measurements of critical properties, such as including flame surface density, flame curvature, fractal dimension, and 3D3C (three-component) velocity fields. Ultimately, these new capabilities are expected to enable datasets that can be used for direct comparison and validation of model and numerical tools, leading to improved design of energy devices with enhanced efficiency and reduced pollutant emissions.

 The broader impact of this work is multifaceted. The proposed research combines several distinct disciplines, involving optical tomography, combustion, and the processing and analysis of large datasets (due to the 3D nature of the diagnostics). This project leveraged such multi-disciplinary efforts to create broader impacts under the context of energy, photonics, and also information technology, all pressing societal issues. Various activities for maximizing the broader impacts of such a multidisciplinary project have been pursued. Many portions of the proposed research have been integrated into the PI? teaching and outreach activities, transformed into course materials and project, and disseminated among academia and engineering communities. Particularly, the PIs worked closely with engineers from several private companies in the area of propulsion and energy, where the research results were directly relevant to the design of next-generation power devices. The PI actively pursued collaborations, both within his home institution and beyond, in areas encompassing medical imaging, large scale parallel computing, and combustion modeling. These collaborations are expected to maximize the benefit of this project, and also train students in a collaborative environment across boundaries of disciplines and institutions. All these efforts are expected to expedite the transformation of new knowledge produced into technological improvements, promote the awareness of pressing societal issues, and ultimately contribute to the solution of energy and environmental sustainability.
